This was something I never even considered before. Are there situations today that the regular police respond to...that they are not positioned to.
I remember in high school talking to a Swedish girl, who told me about high school graduation in Sweden. Everyone rents a big bus and drives around sweden partying. I was shocked and asked her where the police was. And she replied they were everywhere...to ensure and protect the people partying from hurting themselves!!
This blew my mind. Never once until she told me that story had I considered that the police's role not to stop people from doing what they want but was to protect them while they were.
This reaction was followed by me thinking I had just been thinking the wrong way my whole life and I should think more like her. 
It was only on reflecting that I realized, its not necessary a fault of mine...its more systemic than that. I was raised growing up in a country where my parents always told me to watch out and be extra careful around the police cause their job was to try and find a reason to catch us. 
I am beyond privileged to have parents and a family who could protect me, and live in a community that is less racially oppressive than the US...I can not even fully comprehend the effects of growing up in a black community where their understanding and interpretation of the role of the police comes not just from a warning from elders but strong and petrifiynig experiences in childhood. 
I want to think of and discuss situations in which the police are called on today, but probably shouldn't be. What are they? and who should come to aid instead?
I want to keep in mind the risk police offers are taking...if they do show up to a expectedly peaceful scene unarmed and it turns violent (cos guns are still legal in the US, smh) ...what do we expect police or other officers to do?

Biggest Takeaways
1. Measure cohorts and notice and observe engagement chages over time for these cohorts. 
Cohort being people that joined in the same week or so.Most apps decrease over time or reach a cap. If you have network effects, you should be able to see engagement go up over time as network effects add value to the platform

2. DAU/ MAU -> if its 60%, it means a user is on average using the platform 18 days out of a month. The average means this is a skewed metric. Being driven by the extreme users. 
DAU/MAU doesnt make sense if you dont expect daily usage. 
Also, its important to understand how things affect DAU/MAU -> Notifications will bring back the inactive non-daily users and not power users as much, so it'll increase your MAU and not really your DAU, so DAU/MAU may actually go down

3. Engagement vs Retention - They have overlap but think of this example. Weather apps have really low engagement but high retention. You check it for 10 seconds by you come back regularly

4. Frequency, Engagement, Monetization - You want to dominate in at least one of these

5. MAU = New users - Churn + Resurrected - as you scale its hard to increase MAU (or keeo  growth rate high) by trying to go more and more users and engagement/retention become critical 

6. L28 / L7 - How many users use your platform for 1 day a month vs 2 days a month vs ...28 days a month. Why?

2. Measure Goals -> Have people and teams set their goals for a period of time and measure whether they were able to hit it

3. Measure Quality -> find ways to measure quality of work. Less work of higher quality is generally more valuable than lots of low quality work

6. Better work environment -> Set designated areas for deep/silent work and separate areas for collaborative work.

11. Encourage self care and time off - You have to be an example and be loud about this to make other feel okay doing this. 

12. Coach employees on their priorities - Show people how to timebox, and discuss their schedule with them to prioritize whats most valuable to the company. Make this part of your 1-1s

Brain software has four major decision-making centers:

  • 1) Filling in the Want box
  • 2) Filling in the Reality box
  • 3) Goal selection from the Goal Pool
  • 4) Strategy formation

Musk works through each of these boxes by reasoning from first principles. Filling in the Want box from first principles requires a deep, honest, and independent understanding of yourself. Filling in the Reality box requires the clearest possible picture of the actual facts of both the world and your own abilities. The Goal Pool should double as a Goal Selection Laboratory that contains tools for intelligently measuring and weighing options. And strategies should be formed based on what you know, not on what is typically done.

  • When you learn something or are told something, you’re installing a piece of software. If you understand the code (first-principles) of that software, you can apply the code elsewhere. If not, you are blindly running the software.

  • Use “years of experience” only during the recruiting process. After a person is on the team, use results to measure performance
  • Many people think about average cases (usually optimistic) during a contract stage, that’s a mistake. Think about the worst case scenario. That’s what contracts are for.
  • Don’t talk to a person who talked to a person who said something. Your information is guaranteed to be wrong. Talk to the source directly.
